title: What will be The We Company's (WeWork's parent company) end-of-day market capitalization on the day of its initial public offering (IPO)?
possible_answers: More than $25 billion but less than $40 billion
The We Company will not have an IPO before 30 November 2019
correct_answer: The We Company will not have an IPO before 30 November 2019
preds: Given the recent negative news press, SoftBank refinancing, and public ally announced strategy shift which will take time to implement, Wework will not be ready by 11/30, not to mention the substantial securities documentation work required and likely corporate governance overhaul.
PE Bubble will not pop all at once.
With prospective market valuations and opinions appearing to vary from between $15 to 49 Bn and current losses there is a need for a period of reassessment which cannot be completed before 1 Nov 19

The events leading up to the original timeline of their IPO has spooked prospective public market investors. Can't imagine they get this off at a valuation that pleases their private owners (cough cough SOFTBANK).  FLACIDBANK is better off taking the whole thing in at a 75% discount, revamping the board , restructuring the capital structure (something Shatbank could care less about bc hmmm..look at this company they own called Sprint) and then IPOing after the elections. Also, I still don't understand how I deserve any credit for this prediction (assuming it turns out to be correct) given the news flow related to this story. At this point you are testing my reading comprehension vs forecasting skills. The only impressive element at this juncture would be a forecast of $25-40bn with high certainty. Which would imply some wild info edge, trying to be wrong on purpose, or making a bet on the bankers ability to fleece public equity holders. Please GJP , explain how making a forecast about this topic, at this stage, offers any credible measurement of ones forecasting skills? With all this being said, I don't even know why I bothered with this one.

I have never seen such a barrage of comment in the financial media about what a worthless lump of nothing this is even without Neumann and revising the share profile. Cannot see this getting away in a public market at all. The main people who want out - Son and his KSA clients - have other problems as well.
Looks to have huge financial issues.
We Company has an excessive private valuation and no clear path to profitability.  Overall governance problems are ingrained, but there is a push by controlling investors to go public.
I was wrong initially, The bottom has completely fallen out of this IPO

Recent developments and departure of CEO.  Realization of the market that it's a real estate venture not a tech startup. They're burning more than they're earning. This is from August--
https://www.marketwatch.com/story/weworks-ipo-would-be-a-bewildering-way-to-waste-your-money-2019-08-14

From the Economist:
“ WeWork, which provides shared office space, said it would scrap its initial public offering. Last week the company, once considered one of America’s most valuable start-ups, ousted its chief executive, Adam Neumann. It had previously delayed its flotation amid concern from investors—including SoftBank, its biggest—about its management and burgeoning losses.”

Today's WSJ headline confirmed what a redoubled analysis showed - that they are "out of cash", and in severe and extended need of organizational restructure.
WE Company is filing application with the SEC to withdraw the IPO filing.
IPO withdrawn, some reports it's just postponed, but also buzz of bankruptcy. Founder Adam Neumann cashed out $700M, this seems to be the new way to make money.

Darn. 
Forgot to check crowd.   Which was more all in than I was.   Poo...

It has a burn rate of $219,000 per hour. 
Staggering losses.  Fundamentally, the matching incubators to unused realestate is an good.   But so far - entirely sizzle with no track record of sucessful startups.  Current value - probably 12 bil - less than the 19 bil raised to date.   Still, a lot of good talent invested.  Banking (softbank), finance (goldman sachs) ties to harvard rollodexes.. Frie. It needs an IPO to sustain its burn rate.   Its either ipo or bankrupt.   Turns out the probably did Adam a favor by kicking him out of the company.

A less-than $10 billion mkt cap means SoftBank has to recognize a $30 billion valuation "loss" - so I think they would prefer to avoid crystallizing that in the minds of investors & lenders, and calling into question the value of their other positions, and further calling into question their judgment/acumen. 
But if they absolutely need the money - reputation be damned. So 1% to reflect that. Recent housecleaning involved the termination of as many as 20 friends/family members of the former CEO - I had not known the nepotism to be rampant.
Self-dealing by the CEO regarding loans and preferential stock payment compensation pre-resignation (later returned to WeWork) tells me there is more to be discovered and which needs to be unwound before WE can meet even the minimal baseline for "barely legal compliance" with SEC regs for public offerings.
60 days may be enough to clean house - if the markets go on to new highs and beyond. Thus 13% chance of getting a mid-to high end valuation in the range.  $40 billion is out of the question - but you never know - so 1%. With Endeavor puling its IPO and PLTN barely getting a $7 billion market cap following a 12% decline at the close from its $29 offering price - WE comes to market at a  weak period for equities and certainly a skeptical period for IPOs.
We can test that latter speculation in October as we see how earnings season unfolds. Many say analysts will again reduce Q3 forecasts for top-line growth due to unfolding world and domestic weakness in demand. If true - October will have a lot of selling.
Finally - November starts the tax-loss selling season, and coincides with the window dressing customarily engaged by investment funds in order to present the best picture at 12-31-19 FYE.  
Added up - coming to market by Nov 30 seems to be a  bad time to roll out an IPO - though we'd have to test that by assessing what in what months IPOs have come out most often. My guess would be Q2 #1and Q3 #2 - with Q4 a real laggard. We'll soon see.
Reminiscent of Robinhood's disruption of FinTech, and Über and Lyft in transportation.

From the Economist:
“ The Financial Times reported that WeWork, a loss-making provider of shared-office space, has halted the signing of new lease agreements to rein in costs. The company pulled an initial public offering last week because of investor fears that it was overvalued and that Adam Neumann, its co-founder, was out of control. On Tuesday he was ousted as chief executive”
Strong financial pressure for IPO before end of year... but I strongly suspect current shake-down of governance and financials mean an IPO will not happen before 30 Nov.

Whelp I misread this one. Thought SoftBank would try to salvage, but they seems pretty committed to trimming down the business and selling non-core subsidiaries. Such drastic changes can’t support an IPO by the end of November

There are only two months until the end of this challenge.  The financial press is now reporting that a large layoff may be coming soon.  A head count reduction would conserve capital, and thus delay the need to raise new money through an IPO. The capital markets could be forcing WeWork to do what they should have done sooner -- focus on achieving profitability instead of spending Softbank's money on blue sky plans.  Investors have realized that they had been drinking the founder's "Kool Aid."  I now believe that the new management team will downsize the company and focus on becoming profitable, or at least cash flow neutral before relaunching plans for an IPO.  That will take time, a lot more than two months. So I'm switching my bet back to "no IPO before 30 November."  100%

SoftBank announced a $1B injection of funding,  This will a) help stabilize WeWork while they get the new CEO producing and b) instill greater confidence in SoftBank investors on the hopes of a company turnaround.  IPO gets delayed at least one more business quarter.

This is one almighty mess and at present I cannot see the ipo going forward - sheer disconnect between private and public market valuation - ceo being pushed out - core investor concerned about losing face - public markets increasing levels of scrutiny for flashy tech companies who burn cash and are unable to point to future profits any time soon dampening overall appetite - wall street implies valuation between $12bn &15bn - the optics of this whole scenario are shockingly bad
Saw what the crowd had to say...

Why would it NOT have an IPO before 30 Nov?
Because the offer is in disarray, the leadership seems to be floundering and the CEO has just stepped down to take a back seat after a no-confidence vote.  Why would it go through?
Adam Neumann may have stepped down as CEO, but he still has a controlling interest in the company as do other investors - they've been working hard on this IPO and their egos are fully invested. I believe he wants to get the IPO over with, and so do 'they'. An attempt at the IPO is still on the cards for this year. 
However, there is compelling reasons not to continue... so I'm hedging towards it NOT happening before December.  If it does, given recent events and opinions, I doubt it'll be worth more than 25 billion.

If you Google WeWork you can find any number of articles regarding the company's valuation.  I've read several pieces in the financial press that say the value has fallen by about two thirds, from $47B to somewhere in the neighborhood of $15B.  The CEO agreed to step down to become the non-executive chairman, after pressure from investors.  It seems this was done to try to salvage the IPO.  The company needs an infusion of capital or it will have to halt expansion plans. I have no real insight into the thinking of the company's management or investors.  But what makes sense to me is an IPO at a reduced valuation.  Half a loaf (or a third) is better than nothing.  So I've decided to deviate from the crowd, which places the odds of no IPO before November 30 at 94%.  I'm putting the odds at 50%.

Neumann has stepped down as CEO, with two executives who reported to him taking over as co-CEOs [1,2,4]. Is this going to make an IPO in the question timeframe more or less likely?
Arguments for more likely:
- Neumann and his tight grip on the company were said to have had a negative impact on interest by investors. This might change now that he is in a non-executive role and voting power of his shares have been reduced.
- One of the new co-CEOs (Gunningham) is said to have had a positive, mediating impact on Neumann and the course of the company, "to the extent some employees said they referred to him as “shadow CEO” and “the adult in the room”" [1] - having Gunningham in the top job might help restore some confidence by investors, and could lead WeWork to decide to push ahead with the IPO without hiring a new, outside CEO first (see below).
- This hasn't really changed with Neumann stepping down, but without an IPO, WeWork puts a loan package in jeopardy that is a much needed cash injection to keep its operations going [3].  Arguments for less likely:
- The new co-CEOs are perceived as close to Neumann, so it might take bringing in an outside CEO to increase investor confidence prior to an IPO. If they are going to look for a new CEO, this will take time and makes a delay of the IPO until next year more likely.
- Even if WeWork had already planned the marketing and strategy around the IPO, bringing in new leadership almost always leads to some ramp up time and adjustments, making a delay more likely.
- There seem to be plans to cut costs by focusing on the core business and lay-offs [4], with the goal of making the company more attractive to investors. Again, implementing these changes will take time. I am going to increase no IPO, but not as far as some other forecasters and the crowd (currently at 92%). [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-wework-neumann-ceos-newsmaker/wework-chief-neumanns-top-lieutenants-step-up-as-successors-idUSKBN1WA0HA
[2] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-wework-neumann-idUSKBN1W92DX
[3] https://www.reuters.com/article/wework-loan/wework-loan-modified-to-reduce-lender-risk-ahead-of-ipo-idUSL2N264134
[4] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/24/business/dealbook/wework-ceo-adam-neumann.html?action=click&module=Top%20Stories&pgtype=Homepage

Nudging towards No IPO before November 30th due to CEO stepping down news. While new management may be better for the company in the long term, it would appear they need to do some damage control before potential IPO.

Neumann blinked.
But "co-CEOs"?
"Ratchet provision'?
A valuation that keeps weakening - now I read "$15 billion" -  seems generous by today's standards.
If the economy rolls over in 2020, the WeWork thesis gets tested - at a time of attenuated capital levels and funding sources for WeWork to tap.
Seems like strong headwinds for an IPO.
New CEO search process means there is no way the IPO can happen in the stated timeframe.
Seems impossible within this timeframe after the CEO stepped down. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/24/business/dealbook/wework-ceo-adam-neumann.html?action=click&module=Top%20Stories&pgtype=Homepage

- $1.5B in revenue ending Q2 2019; $1.37B in loss sme period
- Softbank is large investor - needs an IPO to keep it going to raise cash.
- CEO unpopular - SoftBank wants him out.  A replacement with a seasoned CEO could stabilize an IPO.
- WeWork recently reduced their IPO target valuation frm $47B to $20 - $30B
- Flexible office space grew YOY 7.6 to 86% - more competitors entering the space
- They are in a line of business that has ease of entry - nothing special about them
- I suspect huge pressure for Neumann to step aside so that the IPO can go through - too much money on the line to wait it out.
- Compared to BXP  which is profitable with similar revenues and at a $20B market cap, I place WeWork going IPO and landing under $20B on day 1

The latest fight between the board of directors and the CEO will delay the IPO indefinitely.  If the CEO wants to make money he will step aside and the IPO will be accelerated, but the company will need to show more solid fundamentals before they prepare a new filing, and that will take time.
THey post phoned the IPO TOUR? What is there product? Furnished offices?

Softbank seeking to remove WE's CEO after a very bad news week for WeWork's Neumann.
Neumann has the votes - but SoftBank has the money.
Who will blink?
They are not looking so good and may want to wait

The market rejected the $40-50bn valuation and so it is not possible to be $40bn or more. Dropping a valuation by far more than 50% would be unprecedented, so far less than $20bn is unlikely. Realistically it will go public next year or the following year after the devastating defeat.

SoftBank is encouraging WeWork to postpone til next year. WeWork is going to hold off until 10/19, but 1.5 months is enough to get the IPO going. I am becoming less confident in the $25-40bn and more confident in postponing, but WeWork needs cash and waiting will not likely result in an improving economic environment
Company needs to get it's sh.. strait before it goes public. Going to take until current tax year has ended to roll off some unwanted debts.

It seems in recent reports (https://www.wsj.com/articles/wework-parent-expected-to-postpone-ipo-11568671322) are showing that WeWork is postponing it's IPO. With the attention this company is getting, there could be more issues that delay an IPO. However, the companies founders may have too much invested to delay again, thus I could see a market cap around where some other recent IPOs have landed (Uber, SmileDirect) on day 1.

too much bad publicity and too many aspects to get 'right' before investor confidence is right - September results could just revive it but let's see.....
There's still significant financial pressure to float before end of year but at this stage I'm just not confident of it being before December.

IPO was reported delayed in NYT earlier in the week from corporate governance matters to weak financial prospects.
It may be wiser to forego an IPO and remain private given the weak market valuations.

I think there's a lot for them to work out yet, seems their valuations maybe were based on false confidence in the past and I'll repeat what others have said about having to justify their valuation estimates. Too high and they'll crash out, too low and maybe confidence in the company wouldn't be as high as they'd like. Finding the balance (historical losses, future plans) will be the biggest challenge so I'm not even sure an IPO will be secured by November this year. It could be back to the drawing board for a while until a more solid plan has been worked out? P/L seems shaky, I'd want more time to build a watertight future plan at least.

Announced they are delaying the IPO.  
https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/17/business/dealbook/wework-ipo.html
They have already delayed to Oct, it could easily get delayed further since 1 month typically isn't enough time to convince prospective investors in the context of an IPO.

We Company confirmed the IPO will be delayed: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-wework-ipo/wework-parent-says-ipo-still-on-despite-setbacks-idUSKBN1W12T6
https://techcrunch.com/2019/09/16/the-we-company-reportedly-will-put-its-public-offering-on-hold/
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/09/16/weworks-on-again-off-again-ipo-delayed-again.html They say they want to go public by the end of the year. Raising probability for no IPO before 30 Nov, at the expense of less than 10bn bucket, because I think one major reason for the delay is major investors (first and foremost Softbank) needing to target a valuation higher than the 10 to 12bn that have been floating around recently. In effect, I am saying they won't go public if they perceive a substantial risk that it could come in below a 10bn valuation.
IPO delayed. Company said they expect to do it "before the end of the year" Latest numbers mentioned around the $10 billion mark.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-wework-ipo/wework-parent-says-ipo-still-on-despite-setbacks-idUSKBN1W12T6
Seems increasingly unlikely they'll go out before December at the earliest, but stay tuned.

Adjusting based on recent wsj article  https://www.wsj.com/articles/wework-parent-expected-to-postpone-ipo-11568671322?emailToken=b47d4489de19ad905d0182067433440fqH2TEb2Gt2VFu5PlDpXe6T2j22jcaTdQ1D63snoSRZN6/54HoqmKWHC9GQXw6hyn2+XbTikKnIphe2hizWLpqTTmInA9QY/hINv50Rx2Nyw%3D&reflink=article_copyURL_share Expected valuation of $15-20m and delay until October do not bode well. Curious what that would equate to in terms of share price? Losing $5-10bn on launch day trading seems unlikely, but it could happen. Likely share price would make it easier to assign a probability to this

Stories in the news support an initial ipo of 10-20 as a starting market cap. IPOs tend to go up in the first day of trading. Many are asking for the company to back-off from their IPO, but that does not seem to be a common occurrence.
Softbank announced 9-13-19 that it would buy $750MM of the new issue - which is estimated to be 25% of the new float.
Mostly basing this off of previous forecasts, as well as the fact that The We Company seems to be losing public confidence and there's a call for it to pull the IPO.

In a normal world this would be pulled, but the major investor who loses is Softbank and no one else cares. Plus they need an IPO to have access to a $6 billion credit facility, and they're talking about accepting a $10 billion valuation to get that done. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-wework-ipo-valuation/exclusive-wework-considers-ipo-valuation-of-as-low-as-10-billion-sources-idUSKCN1VY1PB

Based on cafebedouin reminder about Softbank investment - the aggregate estimated valuation vis-a-vis Softbank's investment aren't adding up to me.
The supermajority changes in governance don't seem to be enough.
Wall Street is falling way out of love with the prior internal valuation of $40 billion to $50 billion - estimates this morning are $10 billiion (?!)
All of this moves the chance of a pulled IPO.
Questionable business model. While the founder has cleaned up disturbing issues regarding payments and super-voting shares, I think his past poor judgement will depress the IPO pricing.
They need money, but they are not at the right valuation to get it from the stock market.
WeWork just announced the IPO is scheduled for Sept 23. Analysts expectations are for less than or equal to $20bn. Will update when I hear more
This will take place and the value is borderline 10 billion

A wild ride - I thought WeWork was estimated north of $50 billion - and yet I read today estimates as "low" as $18 billion, with trouble floating debt to cover cash drain.
I also read of regulatory irregularities regarding self-dealing with the founder.
Thus, adding a chance that the IPO is pulled b/c of either lack of debt market support or SEC compliance issues.
Revising up due to Softbanks guidance suggesting WeWork postpone
The lead investor (Softbank) has a habit of 100-200% overvaluation
SoftBank now urging to shelve IPO

From the FT. "Advisors for the We Company were said to still be testing investor appetite at a valuation of between $15bn and $20bn, according to people briefed on the matter. That is far below the $47bn valuation given to WeWork when SoftBank invested $2bn in the business this year."

High expenses, heavy recession risks, governance and conflict of interest claims, and a low path to profitability. As pointed out in this article (https://seekingalpha.com/article/4289610-wework-one-worst-ipos-2019) WeWorks most similar competitor is valued at only $4bn. This competitor (IWG) also has a rev/sq ft that’s about 23% higher than WeWork.  These concerns seems to be increasing the risk that WeWork puts off its IPO for this year until it can fully address self-dealing among execs and other governance issues. On the other hand, growing recession risks could further jeopardize a company that makes its money by borrowing long term and lending short term.  Investopedia had a good article on what drives IPO valuations:
- demand: while short term leases for office space is likely to be in demand, work from home capabilities and growth of smaller US cities will likely keep workers away from expensive leases in populous cities. In terms of demand for shares of the business, I don’t think WeWorks model is sustainable in an economic downturn.  - Industry Comps: closest competition is valued at a measly $3.7bn -Growth Prospects: subjective, but it seems like this might be the upside. Classification as a tech company could allow WeWork to move with broader indices and possibly allow it to stay at a higher valuation longer.  - Good story: WeWork had this, but it is deteriorating quickly.  All in - I think the IPO gets slashed to $20bn, but it is almost equally likely that it will be postponed.

Bloomberg TV is discussing this issues extensively. It has been said that a minority assume that less than 10 Billion market capitalization is only justified, because long term engagement of WeWork with short term leasing is highly risky. WeWork is not profitable up to now. The world economy slowed and the US economy is at the end of a cycle with signs of weaknesses, too. On the opposite is SoftBank the biggest holder of investments at WeWork and seeing opportunities on long run. I assume that decides.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-wework-ipo-exclusive/exclusive-wework-to-press-on-with-ipo-launch-despite-valuation-concerns-sources-idUSKCN1VR2L6 There is a nontrivial chance, in IPOs like this one, that the truth of the most famous aphorism attributed (probably falsely in this case) to PT Barnum will once again be demonstrated.

Current estimates value the company at around USD 20 billion. That is around 30 billion less than the 47 billion established in the last private financing round. Question is then should the IPO go forward, with a recession also on the horizon. Consensus seems to be that the IPO will go ahead, a roadshow is scheduled for next week, and some debt financing seems to rely on the IPO going forward. Delaying the IPO further would be unlikely to do wonders to the future valuation either. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-wework-ipo-exclusive/exclusive-wework-to-press-on-with-ipo-launch-despite-valuation-concerns-sources-idUSKCN1VR2L6
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/09/06/wework-ipo-scrapping-it-may-be-companys-best-option.html
